Dear Mr. Lingle:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-6992.

Sincerely,
Jennifer Pastorick, Licensing Consultant

INVESTIGATION:
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety,
and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff member at the facility embraced youth in a hug that lasted longer
than a minute. Staff member was rubbing youth's back and placed their
head on top of youth's head. Staff member extended their arms and
youth walked out of her room and embraced in a hug. There are
concerns for sexual grooming.
Investigation Interviews:
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the MDHHS office on
12/16/2022 and via telephone on 1/11/2023. Staff 1 reported he
worked on 12/13/2022. Youth A had self-harming behaviors. Staff 1
used empathy and reality statements throughout the night with Youth A.
Youth A had three incidents of self-harm that resulted staff intervention
to keep her safe. Staff 1 talked to Youth A outside her bedroom door to
help her process her thoughts and feelings. Staff 1 reported Youth A
requested a hug when he was going to leave for the night. Staff 1
agreed to the hug. Staff 1 reported the hug lasted approximately thirty
seconds. Staff 1 described the situation as Youth A asked for a hug
and asked Staff 1 to come into her bedroom for a hug. Staff 1 told
Youth A she could come out to the hall where he was as Staff 1 wanted
it to be on camera. Youth A came into the hall to give Staff 1 a frontal
4

hug. Youth A’s arms went under Staff 1’s arms and around his waist
area as Youth A is short, resulting in her head coming up to his chin.
Staff 1 rubbed Youth A’s back as an indication the hug was over, and
he said goodnight. Staff 1 reported he also told Youth A “You’re going
to be ok kid, do what you need to do.” Staff 1 did a handshake that he
and Youth A made up after they hugged. Staff 1 reported he has
hugged other youth at the facility including Youth B and Youth C. Staff
1 was informed by Chief Administrator he was being removed from
employment due to the hug. Staff 1 reported he never received any
training that hugging youth was not allowed at the facility. Residential
Director told Staff 1 during his orientation in October 2022 that staff
were able to hug youth if the hug was initiated by youth and for a
reasonable situation. Staff 1 reported he had never been provided with
the Professional Boundaries Policy and Procedures prior to Chief
Administrator providing him them when he was dismissed from
employment. Staff 1 reported had he been provided with the
Professional Boundaries Policy and Procedure prior and known that
hugging youth was not allowed, he would have never hugged Youth A.
Staff 1 reported he gave Youth A his coat to wear that evening due to
Youth A being cold. Staff 1 reported he did not see any issues giving
the youth his coat and did not recall policy or procedures addressing
sharing clothing with youth. Staff 1 reported he did not recall if he met
with Youth A in the basement during the shift. Staff 1 reported he
routinely would meet one-on-one with youth per their request to talk
about feelings they had until they were able to meet and talk with their
therapist.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 12/20/2022 and 1/11/2023.
Staff 2 worked on 12/13/2022 with Staff 1. This was the third shift Staff
2 had worked at the facility. Staff 1 told Youth A she looked cold and
took his coat off and put it over her. Staff 2 reported it is not normal
practice to share clothing with youth and this was addressed in
professional boundaries training. Staff 2 reported she had prior
concerns with Staff 1’s professional boundaries as he wanted to be the
youth’s favorite staff. Staff 2 was not able to provide any specific
examples of situations regarding this. Staff 2 was concerned with Staff
1’s professional boundaries. Staff 1 laid outside Youth A’s bedroom on
12/13/2022. Staff 2 did not know how long Staff 1 laid outside Youth
A’s bedroom door as her shift ended prior to Staff 1’s. Staff 2 went
down to tell Youth A goodnight and Staff 2 got up from laying on the
floor. Staff 2 described Staff 1 laying on the floor as Staff 1 sitting up
outside Youth A’s bedroom door where he was using one of Youth A’s
stuffed animals to lean against the door frame. Youth A was standing a
couple feet inside her door when Staff 2 approached. Staff 2 thought it
was odd that Staff 1 was laying outside Youth A’s bedroom door. Staff
2 did not recall if Staff 1 stood up when he saw Staff 2 coming or once
4

Staff 2 reached Youth A's door. Youth A still had Staff 1’s coat on when
she said goodbye to her. Staff 2 reported Youth A asked both her and
Staff 1 for a hug, Staff 2 did not recall who hugged Youth A first
however both her and Staff 1 hugged Youth A. Staff 2 reported she
gave Youth A a two second one arm side hug and Staff 2 gave her a
quick frontal hug. Staff 2 was not concerned with the frontal hug she
witnessed. Staff 2 reported in professional boundaries training it
addressed staff/youth hugging and staff can give youth a side hug for
no more than two seconds, but it is recommended that high fives be
used. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 spent one-on-one time with Youth A and
Youth B during the shift. Staff 1 would talk with the youth about their
lives and typically did so one-on-one in the den or in the basement
which Staff 2 reported was normal areas where staff would talk one-on-
one with youth if they requested it.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 12/21/2022. Staff 3
reported she worked on 12/13/2022 with Staff 1 and Staff 2. Staff 3
reported she noticed Staff 1 and Youth A had a “weird” relationship.
Staff 3 defined “weird” as Staff 1 having a different relationship with
Youth A then other youth in the house however was not able to explain
this. Staff 3 reported Staff 1 put his coat on Youth A by draping it over
her which she did not think was allowed at the facility. Staff 3 has
worked four other shifts with Staff 1 and reported no concerns on those
shifts. Staff 3 received professional boundary training as well as a
recent email from management about professional boundaries. Staff 3
reported she was trained that it is acceptable to give a two second side
hug but no other forms of hugging is acceptable. Staff 3 reported she
has not witnessed any staff hug youth.
Chief Administrator/Complainant was interviewed face-to-face at
the facility on 12/16/2022 and via telephone on 12/14/2022 and
12/20/2022. Chief Administrator reported video footage was being
reviewed for a restraint when video footage of Staff 1 giving Youth A a
frontal hug was found. Chief Administrator reported internal policy
states staff can give youth a side hug for two seconds. Staff are
informed during pre-service training with Residential Director of policy,
procedures and professional boundaries. Chief Administrator
verbalized concern with the hug being a front hug, lasting over thirty
seconds, and the hug being more of a cuddling situation where Staff 1
was rubbing Youth A’s back and lays his head on top of Youth A’s.
Chief Administrator reported the hug appears to be a grooming
behavior. Staff 1 was let go from the facility due to the incident after
consultation with the Director. Chief Administrator reported no other
staff saw the hug occur.
4

Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/16/2022
and 12/29/2022. Youth A reported she was hugged by Staff 1 once a
few weeks ago because she was crying and wanted a hug. Youth A
reported staff are allowed to hug youth if they choose to. Youth A
reported staff have good boundaries with youth at the facility. Youth A
reported staff are only allowed to give youth side hugs. Youth A did not
have any concerns with Staff 1’s boundaries and reported he was
always willing to talk to youth at the facility and described him as the
“mom of the house”. Youth A reported “mom of the house” meant he
was always willing to meet and talk with youth about what difficulties
they were having. Youth A reported she initiated hugs from Staff 1.
Youth A reported she had a special handshake that she did with Staff 1.
Youth A described the handshake as touching fingers and then having
a fist with their thumb and picky out which she reported meant “you
rock”. Youth A reported she taught Staff 1 the handshake as it was a
handshake she use to do with a family member. Youth A did not report
any other physical interactions with Staff 1. Youth A reported she liked
Staff 1 and thought he was “cool”.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/29/2022.
Youth B reported she did not have any concerns with Staff 1 and never
felt uncomfortable around him. Youth B reported she has hugged Staff
1 on a few occasions. Youth B did not report any concerns that she
had with the hugs. Youth B reported Staff 1 is no longer employed at
the facility due to hugging youth as staff are not supposed to hug youth.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/29/2022.
Youth C reported they have never hugged a staff member at the facility.
Youth C did not have any concerns with staff boundaries regarding
physical contact. Youth C did not feel uncomfortable being around
Staff 1.
Residential Director was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/16/2022. Residential Director reported he is the trainer at the
facility. During orientation training, staff are trained in professionalism
which covers what professionalism is, what to wear to work,
confidentiality and physical boundaries. Residential Director reported
sometimes staff have specific questions during training regarding
specifics such as high fives, side hugs, and knuckles however Staff 1
did not ask any specific questions regarding hugs. During training there
is a discussion about setting boundaries around youth who ask for a lot
of side hugs and how this can be addressed. Residential Director
reported Professional Boundaries Policy is covered in training.
Residential Director did not see the hug in person or via video.
Video Reviewed:
4

Video footage of 12/13/2022 in the hallway was reviewed on
12/16/2022. Staff 1 is standing outside Youth A’s bedroom. Staff 1 and
Youth A can be heard whispering however it is unclear what is said.
Staff 1 has his hands in his pockets and is smiling and moving toward
Youth A’s door at which time he places his right hand up to his face
with his pointer finger against his lips in a sign to be quiet. Staff 1 steps
back a little from the door while smiling. Youth A comes into the
doorway and picks up a stuff animal that is laying in the doorway and
then goes back into her bedroom. Staff 1 continues talking in a
whispering voice resulting in it being unknown what he is saying. Staff 1
then puts his arms out and then folds them down in front of him where
his hands are clasped together, and whispers again and then places his
arms back up and open where Youth A comes out of her bedroom in a
coat and embraces Staff 1 in a frontal hug. Youth A wraps her arms
around Staff 1’s waist with her hands placed on his upper back and her
face buried into Staff 1’s chest. Staff 1’s arms wrap around Youth A’s
upper shoulder area and his hands are on her back where he begins
rubbing her back and places his chin resting on top of her head. Youth
A is slowly rubbing Staff 1’s back. Staff 1 and Youth A continue in the
embrace. Staff 1 begins to pull his arms back from the hug and
repositions his chin to have his head turned away from the camera and
his right ear is resting on Youth A’s head. Staff 1’s arms go back fully
around Youth A. Staff 1 continues rubbing Youth A’s back. Staff 1 turns
his head back placing his left ear on Youth A’s head and continues
embracing Youth A. Staff 1’s eyes are closed as he holds Youth A in
the embrace. Staff 1 says something in a low voice that is unable to be
heard through the video. Youth A and Staff 1 break from the
approximately forty second embrace. Staff 1 is talking quietly to Youth
A and then can be heard asking Youth A for his coat. Youth A takes off
the coat she is wearing and hands it to Staff 1. Staff 1 continues talking
to Youth A however it is quiet and cannot be made out what he is
saying.
Additional video footage was viewed from 12/13/2022 on 12/29/2022 to
observe the entire shift Staff 1 worked. Staff 1 was viewed to be
meeting with Youth C at one time in the den and then with Youth A
individually. Staff 1 can be heard talking to the video camera stating he
is doing the therapist role at the facility and apologizes on camera to
the Chief Administrator. Staff 1 is viewed during the shift to hug Youth
A multiple times using frontal hugs, including three times when he is
outside her bedroom door as well as when he meets with her
individually in the den. Staff 1 is viewed to sit outside Youth A bedroom
door on multiple occasions throughout the shift. Staff 1 does not meet
individually with Youth A in the basement during the shift.
Documents Reviewed:
4

• Healthy and Professional Boundaries When Working with Youth
Policy and Procedure states acceptable physical contact as high
fives, elbow bumps, side hugs for no more than 2 seconds, fist
bumps, and pushing a youth on a swing. Non-acceptable
physical contact includes cuddling, a staff or youth laying their
head on any contact point of another’s body. Non-acceptable
body gesture communication includes use of hand gestures,
signals, or signs. Non-acceptable vocal communication include
whispering to a specific youth. Unacceptable (Grooming)
includes sharing of clothing items.
• Staff 1’s personnel file: There was no disciplinary record and
Staff 1 received Professionalism training on 10/10/2022.
• Staff 2 and 3 personnel files: Staff 2 and 3 do not have any
disciplinary record. Staff 2 and 3 received Professionalism
training on 11/14/2022.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as Staff 1 did not follow the
facilities Healthy and Professional Boundaries when Working with
Youth Policy and Procedure as Staff 1 engaged in a frontal hug with
Youth A that lasted over thirty seconds and laid his head on top of
Youth A’s head. Staff 1 and Youth A engaged in a handshake and
hand signals as well as sharing clothing which is nonacceptable per the
facilities policy.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
Description (5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a manner
that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity of the
youth’s behavior, chronological and developmental age, size,
gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma,
and must be done in a manner consistent with the youth’s
treatment plan.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Restraint was not performed per proper technique.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed via telephone on 1/11/2023. Youth A
reported she did not remember being restrained in December. Youth A
stated she did not want to talk any further. Youth A reported she has
felt safe at the facility and if she did not she would tell someone.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on 1/11/2023. Staff 1 reported
Youth A was in her bedroom, and he could hear a banging noise which
4

he assumed was Youth A banging her head against the door. Staff 1
opened Youth A’s bedroom door and saw her head against the door.
Staff 1 went into Youth A’s bedroom and had Staff 2 observe. Youth A
was positioned between the door and wall by the door hinges. Staff 1
lifted Youth A out from behind the door by placing his hands under
Youth A’s elbows and lifted her up to bring her into the hallway. Staff 1
reported this was not a trained technique. Staff 1 reported he was just
attempting to get Youth A out of her bedroom into the hallway. Youth A
was partially standing while Staff 1 brought her into the hallway
however Staff 1 reported it was hard to explain the position she was in.
In the hallway Staff 1 sat Youth A down against the wall. Staff 1
reported he was still holding Youth A by the elbows and Youth A tried to
go back into her bedroom. Staff 1 reported he did not know what Youth
A’s intentions were as she was making statements that she wanted to
die. Staff 1 stopped Youth A from going back into her bedroom by
sitting on the floor next to her and hooking his arm and placing his leg
over Youth A’s leg while Staff 2 hooked Youth A’s left arm and placed
her leg over Youth A’s left leg. Staff 1 reported it was a trained two-
person Primary Restraint Technique (PRT) hold. Youth A was crying
and tried to bang her head against the door behind her while in the
restraint. Staff 1 reported he and Staff 2 leaned Youth A forward to
prevent her from hitting her head as they were in control of Youth A’s
upper body in the restraint. Staff 1 reported he was trained to use his
leg to secure Youth A’s leg. Staff 1 reported the youth’s whose
bedroom door was where the restraint occurred in front of needed to
use the bathroom and Youth A was not calm enough to be released
from the restraint so he informed Staff 2 that they would escort Youth A
into the living room and continue the restraint on the couch. Staff 1
reported he was not trained to restrain on the couch. Staff 1 reported
he wanted to move the restraint to the couch as he thought it would be
more comfortable and help with calming Youth A down.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 12/20/2022 and 1/11/2023.
Staff 2 was concerned with a restraint that occurred during the shift with
Youth A and Staff 1. Staff 2 reported Youth A was restrained in the
hallway due to self-harming behaviors. Staff 1 was on Youth A’s right
side and Staff 2 was on Youth A’s left side in a seated position. Staff 2
reported she and Staff 1 had Youth A’s arms secured however she was
concerned as Staff 1 did not have his arm hooked behind Youth A’s
back. Staff 1 had his arm linked together facing forward and his other
hand on Youth A’s wrist and then placed his leg over Youth A’s leg to
secure her leg. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 did not hook his arm per the
training model. Staff 2 reported the restraint Youth A was in was not a
trained Handle with Care technique. Staff 2 reported it is not a trained
Handle with Care technique for staff to use their legs to secure the
youth’s legs. Staff 2 reported while in the restraint Youth A did lightly
4

try to hit her and Staff 1. Staff 2 did not see Youth A attempt to bite her
or Staff 1. Staff 2 reported she did not see when Youth A was behind
the door regarding how Staff 1 moved Youth A out however when she
was able to see Staff 1 pull Youth A out of her bedroom, Staff 1 had his
arms hooked on Youth A who was in a kneeling position however Staff
1’s hands were not hooked and secured on Youth A’s back per the
trained model.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 12/21/2022. Staff 3
reported she was in the staff office during the restraint with Youth A in
the hallway. Staff 3 came out of the staff office while Youth A was
restrained on the couch in the living room to get a pillow to place behind
Youth A’s head to protect her head in if she attempted to bang her head
back against the couch. Staff 3 reported Staff 1 was on Youth A’s right
side and Staff 2 was on Youth A’s left side. Staff 3 reported she is not
yet trained in restraints and did not know if the restraint was completed
per the trained model.
Residential Director was interviewed face-to-face via Teams
meeting on 1/11/2023. Residential Director is the Handle with Care
trainer at the facility. Consultant reviewed the video of the restraint in
the hallway with Residential Director. Residential Director reported
Staff 1 pulling Youth A out of the bedroom was not a trained technique.
Handle with Care model teaches the restraint occurs where the youth
goes to the floor. If a staff has a youth in a standing PRT then the staff
can move the youth however once a youth is on the ground, the
restraint is to occur in that location unless it is a safety situation such as
being at the top of a staircase. Staff 1 did not have his arms hooked
and placed on Youth A’s back per the model. Staff 1 had a hold of
Youth A’s bicep area which is not a secure and safe hold. Residential
Director reported Staff 1 and Staff 2 had Youth A in a two person PRT
which is not a trained Handle with Care technique as if there are two
staff then one would be the primary doing the PRT and the second staff
would secure the youths legs. Residential Director reported using a leg
to secure the youth’s leg is not a trained technique and that the only
time this technique would be used in in a one-on-one PRT with a small
child. Residential Director reported Handle with Care does not have a
restraint technique for restraining on a couch.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/16/2022 and via telephone on 12/14/2022 and 12/20/2022. Chief
Administrator reported he reviewed the restraints that were on video
from 12/13/2022 involving Youth A. Chief Administrator reported the
restraint in the hallway lasted longer than he thought was necessary as
Youth A was calm and should have been let go. Chief Administrator
was not sure if the restraint was completed per Handle with Care
4

technique. Chief Administrator reported the restraint in the living room
was unwarranted as Youth A was just “flailing around”. He reported he
thinks the restraint was completed per Handle with Care technique.
The complainant is this consultant as during interviews concerns
regarding the restraint were discussed.
Video Reviewed:
Video footage of 12/13/2022 Youth A restraint was reviewed on
1/09/2022. The restraint initiated outside Youth A’s bedroom in the
hallway. Staff 1 and Staff 2 are standing outside Youth A’s closed
bedroom door where a banging noise can be heard on the video. Staff
1 is heard telling Youth A he needs to keep her safe and if she
continues banging her head, he will have to enter her bedroom. Staff 1
stated he is going to count to five. The banging noise can still be
heard. Staff 1 counts to five and then enters Youth A’s bedroom. Staff
1 can be heard asking Youth A to stop banging her head against the
door. Staff 2 is standing outside Youth A’s closed bedroom door where
now Youth A and Staff 1 are inside the bedroom. Staff 2 opens the
bedroom door. Staff 1 is in a kneeled seated position with his hands on
Youth A’s upper arms and is viewed scooting backwards out of Youth
A’s bedroom doorway pulling Youth A with him into the hallway. Staff
1’s hands remained positioned on Youth A’s upper arms by having his
hands wrapped around her upper arm. Youth A pulled her arms away
to get back into her room. Staff 1 pulled Youth A back towards him with
his hands placed around Youth A’s upper arms. Staff 2 transitions into
assist. During the transition Youth A is able to get to her feet and Staff
1 and Staff 2 transition to their feet and have Youth A in an escort hold.
Staff 1 secured Youth A’s right arm. Staff 2 secured Youth A’s left arm
and they transition to a seated restraint. Staff 1 used his left arm to go
under Youth A’s armpit from behind. Staff 2 secured Youth A’s left arm
with her left arm however is unable to position her body behind Youth A
as they are sitting on the ground resulting in Staff 2 being faced the
opposite direction of Youth A and Staff 1. Youth A began to bang her
head back against a bedroom door that is behind her. Staff 1
transitioned his left arm to hook Youth A’s right arm and places his left
hand behind Youth A’s head to enable Youth A from banging her head.
Youth A is screaming for Staff 1 and Staff 2 to let her go. Youth A
moved her legs and Staff 1 placed his left leg over Youth A’s right leg to
secure her leg. Youth A is tried to pull away from Staff 1 and Staff 2.
Staff 1 and Staff 2 continue holding Youth A as she is sitting crying on
the floor. Staff 1, Staff 2, and Youth A are positioned in front of another
youth’s door who tried to come out to use the bathroom and is told to
wait. Staff 1 and Staff 2 transitioned Youth A to a standing escort and
escorted Youth A to the living room. Staff 1 maintained on the right of
Youth A and Staff 2 on the left. Youth A is attempted to get out of the
4

escort. Staff 1 and Staff 2 took Youth A to the couch in the living room
and continued restraining Youth A. Staff 1 is on Youth A’s right side
securing her right arm and Staff 2 is on Youth A’s left side securing her
left arm. Staff 1 placed his left leg over Youth A’s right leg and Staff 2
does the same with her right leg over Youth A’s left leg. Youth A is
asked Staff 1 and Staff 2 to release her from the restraint. Staff 3
comes and placed a pillow behind Youth A’s head per Staff 1’s request.
Staff 1 is talked to Youth A telling her to calm down. Youth A is not
resisting the restraint. Youth A continued to be held in the restraint.
Documents Reviewed:
• South Bluff Physical Restraint policy states the Primary Restraint
Technique (PRT) is the preferred method. Staff stand behind the
youth, hook youth’s arms with theirs, staff places open hands
together on the youth’s back. If the youth continues to resist, it
may be necessary to perform a takedown to the floor by staff
stepping back with one leg, dropping their knee to the ground one
at a time, into a sitting position. A second staff can be used to
support the legs by placing both arms around the legs at the
knees.
• Teaching Family Homes of Upper Michigan Youth Incident Report
dated 12/13/2022: Banging noises were heard inside Youth A’s
bedroom. Staff 1 entered Youth A’s bedroom and escorted Youth A
to the hallway. Staff 2 assisted with the escort. De-escalation
techniques were used for thirty minutes. Staff escorted Youth A to
the main room to accommodate other youth needing to access the
bathroom. Staff escorted Youth A to the couch and continued de-
escalation for twenty minutes. The incident report did not address
how the youth was held in the restraint.
• MiSACWIS Incident Report 145950196 and 145950200 both
dated 12/13/2022 were consistent with the Teaching Family
Homes of Upper Michigan Youth Incident report dated
12/13/2022.
• Handle with Care Manual PRT demonstrates staff standing
behind the youth and hooking the youth’s arms with theirs and
placing open hands together on the youths back. If the standing
PRT transitions to a takedown to the floor, staff takes a long step
back and lowers the center of gravity causing the youth to be off
balance. Staff’s palms are against the youth’s back to support
their weight. Staff lowers their knee to the floor, slowly staging
the youths into a sitting position. Staff drops their other knee to
be in the “settle” position and the youth is in the sitting position.
A two-person takedown the primary staff takes over to secure
both of the youth’s arms in the PRT. The second staff drops
their knees to the floor and is holding the youth legs at the
4

knees. The staff securing the youth’s knees signals to the staff
in the PRT to initiate the takedown. The staff in the PRT steps
back and drops to their first knee and then second knee and
“settle” with their knees on the ground and their buttock resting
on the heels of their feet. This brings the youth to a sitting
position. The staff securing the youth’s knees can continue
securing the legs if the youth is kicking.
• Staff 1’s personnel file: Staff 1 received Handle with Care
training on 10/17/2022.
• Staff 2’s personnel file: Staff 2 received Handle with Care
training on 11/22/2022.
• Staff 3’s personnel file: Staff 3 is not currently trained in Handle
with Care.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as Staff 1 and Staff 2 did not use
a trained Handle with Care technique to restrain Youth A. Staff 1 lifted
Youth A by her elbows out of her room into the hallway. Staff 1 did not
have the proper hold on Youth A’s arms when he was in the seated
one-person restraint with Youth A as his hands were on Youth A’s
upper arms holding her arms resulting in Youth A being able to pull
away from Staff 1. Handle with Care model trains a primary restraint
technique by hooking the youth’s arms with theirs, placing open hands
together on the youth’s back.
Staff 2 goes in to assist Staff 1 at which time Youth A stands up and
Staff 1 and Staff 2 have Youth A in a standing escort. Staff 1 and Staff
2 go from the standing escort to a seated position on the floor with
Youth A. This is not a trained Handle with Care technique. Handle with
Care model trains for one staff to take over in the primary restraint
technique and the second staff moves to securing the youths legs
above the knee and signals to the primary staff to initiate the takedown
by taking a deep step back and dropping their knee and then dropping
the other knee to bring the youth into a sitting position.
Youth A was escorted by Staff 1 and Staff 2 into the living room and
transitioned back into a restraint with Staff 1 on Youth A’s right and
Staff 2 on Youth A’s left in a seated position on the couch. Staff 1 and
Staff 2 secured Youth A’s legs by each placing one of their legs over
hers. This was not a trained Handle with Care technique.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
The facility needs to update their staffing pattern to provide guidance,
job mentoring, and in the moment coaching for staff as they have a lot
of unexperienced/new staff.
The facility viewed the restraint as two separate restraints- one in the
hallway and a second in the living room. This restraint was one
4

restraint as the youth was restrained, placed into an escort, and
restrained once in the living room. Due to staff never disengaging from
the restraint to the escort and back to the restraint, it is one incident.
Conclusion Violation Established

Description be limited to:

Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed via telephone on 1/11/2023. Youth A
reported she did not remember being restrained in December. Youth A
stated she did not want to talk any further.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on 1/11/2023. Staff 1 reported
Youth A was not calm while in the restraint in the hallway. Youth A was
attempting to bite and hit Staff 1. Staff 1 reported the restraint
continued due to Youth A continuing to be escalated and making
statements that she wanted to die, she continued yelling and crying.
Youth A was not following staff directions to calm down and agree to
talk to staff. Staff 1 reported Youth A was continuing to be a serious
threat of harm as she was not complying with Staff 1’s directions to
calm down and agree to talk to staff as she was fighting the restraint.
Staff 1 reported once on the couch in the living room, Youth A
eventually calmed enough and agreed to talk to staff at which time the
restraint was released.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 12/20/2022 and 1/11/2023.
Staff 2 reported Youth A began to calm down in the restraint and Staff 2
felt that it was time to release Youth A. Staff 2 gave Staff 1 a look to
indicate it was time to release however Staff 1 stated to Youth A he
would not be releasing Youth A until he knew that Youth A was not
going to hurt herself. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 was aware of her
indicating they should release Youth A from the restraint as she would
look at him and then Youth A and every time she did, Staff 2 would
state to Youth A they were not releasing. Staff 2 reported the restraint
lasted longer than necessary and she wanted to stop the restraint
however did not want to go against Staff 1 in front of the youth. Staff 2
reported Youth A was no longer resisting the restraint in the hallway
and she did not feel Youth A was a risk to herself. Youth A had calmed
down as she was no longer screaming, moving around in the restraint
4

and was sitting quietly with her head down. Staff 2 reported she had
loosed her arm that was hooked securing Youth A’s arm as she did not
feel the restraint needed to continue. Staff 2 loosed her grip in the
restraint in the hallway prior to Youth A being escorted to the living
room and restrained on the couch. Staff 2 did resecure her grip going
into the escort as Youth A began resisting once in the living room. Staff
2 reported she did not feel the escort or continuation of the restraint in
the living room was necessary as Youth A was no longer a high risk.
Residential Director was interviewed face-to-face via Teams
meeting on 1/11/2023. Residential Director reported staff are trained
to only restrain youth until they are no longer a risk of harm to themself
or others. Staff are trained to not hold a youth in a restraint until the
youth is compliant, meaning the youth may still be yelling however once
the immediate threat of serious physical harm is gone, the youth is to
be released from the restraint. Residential Director reported the letting
go process should have started when Youth A was still in the hallway
as he did not see a reason in the video where Youth A was combative
or demonstrated a level of high risk that would allow for the restraint to
continue. Residential Director reported he did not see a need for Youth
A to be escorted to the living room and placed back into a restraint as it
could have ended in the hallway.
The complainant is this consultant as during interviews concerns
regarding the restraint were discussed.
Video Reviewed:
Video footage of 12/13/2022 Youth A restraint was reviewed on
1/09/2022. Youth A can be seen in the video calming down by her
body language relaxing as she sits and quietly cries in the hallway.
Staff 1 and Staff 2 continue to hold Youth A in the restraint. Consultant
did not see in the video where Youth A attempted to bite or hit Staff 1.
Documents Reviewed:
• South Bluff Physical Restraint policy states restraints must not
last longer than the minimal duration of time it takes for a youth to
calm down and to restore safety. Physical restraint must last only
as long as the threat of physical harm is clearly apparent. This
does not include restraining until the youth calms down. The
youth may still be out of emotional control and yelling, moving
around the area, running, but is no longer a clear threat of
physical harm to himself or others and, therefore, making
physical restraint not necessary.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as Youth A was restrained longer
than needed to end the threat of serious physical harm. Staff 2 reported
Youth A calmed down while restrained in the hallway as she was not
4

resisting the restraint and was sitting quietly with her head down. Staff
2 loosed her grip in the restraint as she did not feel Youth A was a risk
any longer. Video shows Youth A sitting on the floor, not resisting the
restraint, crying while continuing to be restrained.
Conclusion Violation Established
